tossups.question: This phenomenon’s evolution has been linked to a loss in short period sequence interspersion and a higher density of MHC genes. The WAIR hypothesis and the cursorial model are two classical theories for the evolution of this phenomenon. In some species, the evolution of this phenomenon is linked to the development of the plagiopatagium. Animals with this ability typically develop (*) hypoxia tolerance mechanisms like mitochondria-rich, type IIa muscle fibers. The furcula and the keel are specialized structures in animals with this ability. It doesn’t involve water, but the evolution of elongated autopods and the retention of interdigital webbing contribute to this ability. For 10 points, name this ability possessed by bats and most birds.
tossups.answer: flight [accept word forms and answers mentioning flight in any particular species; prompt on answers mentioning things like “having wings or being a bird”; do not accept or prompt on answers mentioning migration]

tossups.question: After a major defeat for this movement, Lord Elcho supposedly called out after his commander, telling him to “run, you damned cowardly Italian!”. That commander escaped to the Isle of Skye disguised as a maid named Betty Burke. James Wolfe legendarily refused to kill wounded soldiers of this movement at Falkirk. The Earl of Mar led this movement in an uprising that was defeated at (*) Sherrifmuir. John Cope was defeated in a victory for this movement at Prestonpans. “Butcher” Cumberland delivered a decisive defeat to this movement at Culloden. Bonnie Prince Charlie was a celebrated leader of this movement, which sought to restore the loser of the Battle of the Boyne. For 10 points, name this movement, which sought to restore James II and the Stuarts.
tossups.answer: Jacobites

tossups.question: A book by William Chittick and Sachiko Murata claims that this practice, along with prayer, is a form of purification comparable to ablution. The Surah At-Tawbah includes those who are fi sabilillah and recent converts as asnaf, the term for those who should receive the benefits of this practice. Shia and Sunni jurists differ over whether Imams or (*) state institutions should administer this practice. Those who possess nisab are obligated to perform this practice, a special form of which occurs before the beginning of Eid-al-Fitr. Unlike the similar practice of sadaqah, this practice is mandatory, as it is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. For 10 points, name this Islamic practice of giving 2.5% of excess wealth to the needy.
tossups.answer: zakat [prompt on almsgiving; prompt on charity; prompt on taxpaying or taxes]

tossups.question: In this literary work, a character has a beard wrapped in gold threads and carries a holly bough. This work explains the five virtues symbolized by a gold pentagram. This work and three less-famous ones were found in the codex Cotton Nero A.x. (“A 10”). It is the most notable poem to use a device common in alliterative verse called the (*) bob-and-wheel. A character in this poem receives hunted animals in exchange for kisses, but does not give up a girdle given to him by Lady Bertilak. The Pearl Poet is credited with writing this poem, which opens at a Christmas feast where the second title character challenges those present to a beheading contest. For 10 points, name this epic poem written in Middle English about a member of the Round Table and his colorfully-named opponent.
tossups.answer: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight

tossups.question: A John Marshall designed building based on the architecture of this country is a former flax mill known as Temple Works. The Harrods department store in London contains a hall inspired by this country's architecture. The Wafi Center in Dubai contains several faux relics based on artwork from this country. One building modelled on this country's architecture is capped by the brightest (*) spotlight in the world. Peter Hemmingway designed a series of greenhouses based on this country's architecture in Edmonton, Canada. Buildings from this country inspired the Luxor Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas. The I.M. Pei designed entrance to the Louvre is modelled off of structures from this country. For 10 points, name this home country of the Giza Pyramid Complex.
tossups.answer: Egypt

tossups.question: In the Rebirth series, this character's father imprisoned two different versions of Timothy Drake in an attempt to change the timeline. In the Doomsday Clock series, Dr. Manhattan is unable to see beyond when this character apparently punches him back in time. After inhaling magic sneezing powder, this character sneezed away the Solar System. In the (*) Injustice series, this character serves as High Chancellor and kills Shazam and the Joker. This character is seemingly killed by Doomsday in a comic series titled "The Death of [this character]”. This character works as a reporter for the Daily Planet and is the love interest of Louis Lane. For 10 points, name this DC Comics superhero, a native of Krypton whose secret identity is Clark Kent.
tossups.answer: Superman [or Kal-el; accept Clark Kent before read]

tossups.question: The Gateway [these compounds]-MAPS is an NIH-sponsored database for genomic and structural data on these compounds. The Hansch pi coefficient measures solubility in solutions of these compounds. Free radicals steal electrons from these compounds to produce aldehydes like MDA in a reaction measured using the TBARS assay. A microdomain of these compounds is isolated based on their resistance to detergents like Triton X-100, and is their namesake (*) raft. PIP2 is one of these compounds modified to act as a signaling molecule. That class of these compounds consists of two hydrophobic “tails” and a phosphate group “head”, and adopt a bilayered structure in the cell membrane. For 10 points, name these macromolecules defined by their solubility in nonpolar solvents, which include steroids.
tossups.answer: lipid(s) [or fatty acids; accept LIPID-MAPS, lipid peroxidation or lipophilicity or lipid raft; accept specific lipids, such as phospholipids or sphingolipids; prompt on nonpolar or hydrophobic compounds]

tossups.question: While doing this activity, a character eating mulberries tells the narrator he would “sooner eat dirt” than lie to him. At the end of a novel, the protagonist is doing this activity when he observes that a character is smiling for the first time since the news that he might have to return to an orphanage prompted a suicide attempt in a hotel’s bathtub. The phrase (*) “For you, a thousand times over” is first said during this activity. After a competition involving this activity, the narrator does not intervene when his friend and servant, a Hazara boy named Hassan, is raped in an alley. A Thousand Splendid Suns is the follow-up to a novel titled for this activity about Amir, who moves to America from Afghanistan. For 10 points, name this activity, which titles a novel by Khaled Hosseini.
tossups.answer: kite running [or kite fighting; accept anything involving the flying of kites; accept The Kite Runner]

tossups.question: Gytha, the mother of a king of this name, offered to pay his body’s weight in gold for a proper burial. A king of this name offered “seven feet of earth” in the prelude to a battle in which a giant axeman killed forty people on its namesake structure. With the support of Tostig, a king of this name defeated Edwin and Morcar of Northumbria at (*) Fulford. Huscarls under a king of this name were decimated by a force that landed at Pevensey. Two kings of this name fought each other at the battle of Stamford Bridge. A king of this name was depicted with an arrow in his eye in the Bayeux Tapestry. For 10 points, give this name shared by a Viking invader and an English king defeated by William the Conqueror at Hastings.
tossups.answer: Harold [accept Harold Godwinson or Harald Hardrada or Harald Sigurdsson or Harald III of Norway]

tossups.question: In one painting of this type created while its artist was in Padua, a winged Time holds a scythe and an hourglass to accompany Zephyr and Flora to the title Triumph of Aurora. Another painting of this type by the same artist shows Apollo extending a royal scepter while Mercury flies a crown toward an allegorical depiction of the Spanish monarchy. In addition to those works, (*) Tiepolo also created a massive work of this type for the Wurzburg residence. Depictions of Rehoboam and Asa and the separation of land from sea are scenes from a series of paintings of this type by a different artist. For 10 points, name this type of painting, such as The Creation of Adam, which Michelangelo painted using intricate scaffolding to decorate the Sistine Chapel.
tossups.answer: ceiling paintings [or ceiling frescoes; prompt on fresco or paintings with “in what type of location”; prompt on answers mentioning paintings in a (Wurzburg) palace with “in what location in the building?”; accept answers mentioning ceiling paintings specifically by Tiepolo or Michelangelo] (all power clues are by Tiepolo)

tossups.question: This poet wrote “Frost and sun - the day is wondrous!” in his poem “Winter Morning,” which is memorized by many schoolchildren in his home country. At age 18, this man wrote the poem “Ode to Liberty,” which led to his banishment. His most famous love poem, dedicated to Anna Kern, opens “I loved you, and perhaps I love you still.” This man branded himself as “The (*) African” due to his great-grandfather, the Black nobleman Abram Gannibal. In a narrative poem by this author, Parasha’s house is destroyed in a flood that does not carry away the title statue of Peter the Great. In one of his novels, the title character attends Tatyana’s name day celebration, where he is challenged to a duel by Lensky. For 10 points, name this Russian author of The Bronze Horseman and Eugene Onegin.
tossups.answer: Alexander Pushkin [or Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin]

tossups.question: A rebel in this modern-day state was killed after its governor Henry Sloughter (pronounced “slaughter”) was convinced to sign his death warrant while drunk. A group of Sephardim who emigrated to this state from Recife (“re-SEE-fay”) became the oldest Jewish congregation in the US. It’s not Pennsylvania, but Andrew Hamilton, the man who designed Independence Hall, served as the defense lawyer during a (*) libel trial in this state. Jacob Leisler rose up in rebellion against Francis Nicholson in this state. Governor William Cosby sued newspaper editor John Peter Zenger in this state in a case that established freedom of the press. The English took this state in 1664 from a peg-legged governor named Peter Stuyvesant (sty-ve-SONT). For 10 points, name this state where the city of New Amsterdam developed into its largest city.
tossups.answer: State of New York

tossups.question: ELENA is a ring-shaped device at this facility designed to produce the “extra low energy” type of a certain particle. That particle is the heavier of two constituent molecules whose freefall acceleration researchers at this facility are measuring in the GBAR experiment. Another set of experiments conducted at this facility produced the first evidence of the W and Z bosons. Those were the (*) UA1 and UA2 experiments. Experiments at this facility commonly make use of a device in which an iridium rod is targeted with beams of protons and anti-protons accelerated in a synchrotron. In 2012, researchers at this facility announced the discovery of the Higgs Boson. For 10 points, name this facility near Geneva that houses the world’s largest high-energy particle collider.
tossups.answer: CERN [accept Large Hadron Collider or LHC; accept European Organization for Nuclear Research; accept Proton-Antiproton Collider (SppS) or the Super Proton Synchronton (SPS)]

tossups.question: A book by E. Franklin Frazier argued that businesses created by these people were incapable of affecting real change. Ritualized ways of displaying masculinity among these people were analyzed in a book written by Richard Majors. Another book claimed that these people were subjected to a vicious cycle that could be ended through the "principle of cumulation." Those books are Cool Pose and An American Dilemma. A report by Pat (*) Moynihan claimed that a history of oppression among these people created a "destructive vein" in their culture. Another book about these people describes them as being "within the veil" and impacted by a "double consciousness." For 10 points, name this racial group, whose "Souls" were written about by W.E.B. DuBois.
tossups.answer: Black people/folks [or African Americans; accept respectful equivalents; do NOT accept or prompt on just "Africans"] (the book from the first line is The Black Bourgeoisie)

tossups.question: According to Latin sources, this man was seduced by Venus while he slept in a cave and then mistook Candiope for the goddess and comitted incest. Antoninus Liberalis claimed that two daughters of this man, Menippe and Metioche, were turned into comets after they died. This man was accompanied by the bronze man Cedalion after he lost his eyesight. After being blinded by his father, (*) Oenopion, this man had his sight restored at Lemnos by standing in the light of Helios. This man was accompanied by the dog Sirius and was killed by a creature sent by Gaia after he boasted that he would kill every animal on Earth. For 10 points, name this hunter from Greek myth who was killed by Scorpio and turned into a constellation.
tossups.answer: Orion

tossups.question: In a pamphlet supporting these people, Elizabeth Dawbarn described "silly Louisa, who admires liberty," whom she contrasts with Clara Neville. These people are described as having a "body natural" and "body politic" in a book by Ernst Kantorowics. The "thirst for absolute power" is described as the "natural disease" of these people by Thomas (*) Paine in his Common Sense. The leadership of these people is identified along with tribalism by Max Weber as a type of "traditional government." A constitutional form of the rule of these people was defended in Reflections on the Revolution in France by Edmund Burke . For 10 points, name these hereditary leaders, whose absolute rule was advocated for in Leviathan.
tossups.answer: kings [accept monarchs; accept queens; accept royals or royalty; accept emperors or empresses; prompt on dictator or sovereigns; prompt on rulers]

tossups.question: The assassination of a prime minister of this country was defended by thousands of letters written in blood; that assassination was known as the May 15 Incident. Radhabinod Pal is revered as a hero in this country for his dissent in a war crimes trial. This country’s first prime minister was assassinated at a railway station, with his death justified by a list of fifteen reasons written by (*) An Jung-geun. During a massacre by this country’s army, Nazi John Rabe created a “Safety Zone” to protect this country’s victims. Iris Chang criticized this country for ignoring war crimes perpetrated by its Imperial Army. For 10 points, name this country that perpetrated the Rape of Nanking during World War II.
tossups.answer: Japan [accept Nippon or Nihon]

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read the notes slowly, pausing between dashes. In one of this composer’s violin concertos, the soloist enters over string tremolos with the notes “C sharp - D - A sharp - B - long F sharp.” In another work by this composer, the solo violin enters on a low B, followed by a rapid ascent up an E major scale to B two octaves higher, before launching into a Habañera-esque melody. One of this composer’s operas includes a Danse Bacchanale that depicts (*) Philistines preparing a sacrifice. This composer of Havanaise dedicated both his third violin concerto and Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso to Pablo de Sarasate. This composer of the opera Samson et Delilah quoted from his own Danse Macabre to portray skeletons dancing in the “Fossils” movement of another work. For 10 points, name this composer of a work whose movements include “The Swan”, Carnival of the Animals.
tossups.answer: Camille Saint-Saëns [DO NOT accept or prompt on a partial last name]

tossups.question: A character who dies in one of these places is addicted to laxatives and rotisserie chicken. After hearing Brahms’ Alto Rhapsody, William Styron visits one of these places in his memoir Darkness Visible. While in one of these places, a character observes a dog who runs onto the highway while chasing geese. Susanna Kaysen’s time in one of these places is the focus of her memoir (*) Girl, Interrupted. In one novel, the Acutes vote to watch the World Series in one of these places. In that novel set in one of these facilities, a half-Native American character who pretends to be deaf and dumb, Chief Bromden, smothers Randle McMurphy after he is lobotomized by Nurse Ratched. For 10 points, name this kind of place, the setting of Ken Kesey’s novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.
tossups.answer: mental hospitals [or psychiatric hospitals; or mental asylums; or insane asylums; or mental institutions; or psychiatric institutions; prompt on hospitals]

tossups.question: One technique that exploits a variant of this process to manipulate index variables was originally introduced in ALGOL 60 and is called Jensen’s device. A partial variant of this process is said to “residualize” the program it acts on by precomputing static inputs to improve efficiency. A helper sub-routine called thunk may be generated to facilitate calculations in this process. High-level (*) CPUs typically make use of a paradigm for performing this process based on data availability instead of on initial ordering. When this process occurs to an expression as soon as it is bound to a variable it is termed “eager”, in contrast to its more delayed “lazy” version. For 10 points, name this basic computing process performed on the arguments of a function’s call.
tossups.answer: evaluation [accept eager/lazy/partial/out-of-order/call-by-name evaluation or word forms such as evaluate; prompt on call-by-name or call alone with “what does this do to a function’s arguments?”]

bonuses.leadin: This action occurs as revenge for the rape of Lavinia, whose hands and tongue are cut off by the rapists. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: baked into a pie [accept cooked or other synonyms for baked; accept anything involving being presented as food]
parts: Name this manner of death suffered by Chiron and Demetrius, who are then presented to their mother Queen Tamora, in the play Titus Andronicus.
Chiron and Demetrius are baked into a pie in this man’s play Titus Andronicus, which can be found in his First Folio.

Titus Andronicus’ chief antagonist is this character, the Moorish lover of Queen Tamora. He tells Chiron “Villain, I have done your mother” in one of the earliest recorded “yo mama” jokes in literature.

bonuses.leadin: According to tradition, this was the first oyashima island created by Izanagi and Izanami. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island separated from Shikoku by the Naruto Strait. This is the largest island located in the Seto Inland Sea.
Awaji Island is separated from this other island by the Akashi Strait. This island is home to the cities of Tokyo and Kyoto and is home to the majority of Japan's population.

Awaji island was at the epicenter of the Great Hanshin Earthquake, which is often named for this city. This city lies on the southern end of Honshu and is the namesake and origin of a famous kind of Wagyu beef.

bonuses.leadin: A meshwork of motile cyanobacteria and sulfate-reducing bacteria have been found to be the cause of “black-band disease”, which impacts these organisms. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: corals [or coral reefs or coral polyps]
parts: Name these organisms that are also afflicted by the similarly named white-band disease and yellow-band disease. Rapid wasting of these organisms has been tentatively linked to overfeeding by the stoplight parrotfish.

One of the largest man-made threats to coral reefs is this climate change-associated process in which coral polyps expel endosymbiotic algae. This phenomenon’s name refers to the loss in coloration by corals undergoing it.

The far more interestingly named, skeletal eroding band disease, has uniquely been shown to be the result of an infection by one species of these ciliate microorganisms from genus Halofolliculina. A different species from that genus of these organisms was linked to a unique Caribbean coral disease outbreak in 2006.

bonuses.leadin: After a commander captured in this battle promised to hunt the victor down and “exhibit him in Constantinople”, the victor declared “my punishment is far heavier. I forgive you and set you free.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1071 battle where Andronikos Doukas’ betrayal led to the capture of Romanos IV Diogenes by a Seljuk army.
This empire was defeated at Manzikert. Turkish armies under Mehmed II eventually conquered this empire’s capital in 1453.
This Seljuk sultan defeated the Byzantine force at Manzikert. He employed the vizier Nizam al-Mulk, author of the Siyasatnama, or “Book of Government”.

bonuses.leadin: In syntactic trees based on X-bar theory, these phrase components may be depicted with any number of corresponding complements. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the term for these phrase components, the words whose usage determines the syntactic category of a given phrase.
In most languages, these types of words tend to be the heads of a phrase. These words typically identify things such as people, places, and objects.

When creating syntactic trees, the location of the head determines whether a sentence possesses the left or right form of this property. Because Japanese is nearly always head-final, phrases in Japanese usually have trees with the leftward form of this property.

bonuses.leadin: Ben Vereen and Patina Miller each won Tonys for portraying the leads in the original Broadway production of this musical. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Steven Schwartz musical that frequently employs distancing effects and fourth wall breaks by the Leading Player and the troupe. The title character sings about his dreams to some scholars in “Corner of the Sky” and a mock battle is portrayed in an exceptionally jazzy manner in this musical’s song “Glory”.

This iconic jazz choreographer directed and provided the libretto for the original run of Pippin. This choreographer’s trademark style frequently incorporated moves like jazz hands, turned-in knees, and tipped hats.

Fosse also won the Best Director Academy Award for his film adaptation of this Kander and Ebb musical set in Weimar Germany’s Kit-Kat Club. That film adaptation of this musical starred Liza Minnelli as Sally Bowles.

bonuses.leadin: Vasates quadripedes is a species of mite that causes one of these afflictions in maple trees, and the study of these growths is called cecidology. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: smut [accept corn smut or sugarcane smut]
parts: Name these benign, tumor-like plant growths. In the laboratory, the “crown” type of these growths can be induced by dipping Arabidopsis seedlings in a liquid culture of Agrobacterium.

In North America and Europe, spherical galls are most commonly found on the branches of oak trees due to the larvae of these insects. Like ants and bees, these insects, which include hornets and yellow-jackets, are members of the order Hymenoptera.

Galls may also form due to this other type of fungal plant disease that particularly concerns staple crop farmers. Two different organisms in the Ustilago genus are responsible for the onset of these diseases in sugarcane and corn.

bonuses.leadin: Authors who wrote in a genre of literature named for these places include Caroline Lee Hentz and William Gilmore Simms. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Thomas [accept Thomas Nelson Page or Thomas Dixon]
parts: Name this type of place. Charles W. Chesnutt’s The Conjure Woman contains many tales set in these places, which were influenced by Joel Chandler Harris’ stories of characters like Br’er Rabbit.
William Gilmore Simms wrote The Sword and the Distaff as a rebuke to this influential anti-slavery novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe.

One author with this first name romanticized plantation life in novels like Red Rock. A white supremacist author with this first name and the last name Dixon wrote The Leopard’s Spots and The Clansman, the latter of which was turned into the film The Birth of a Nation.

bonuses.leadin: Six’s technique was a preparatory method for this style of artwork exemplified by the works of Nikosthenes and Psiax. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: black-figure style [accept but OTHERWISE DO NOT MENTION black-on-red]
parts: Name this earlier of the two major styles of Greek vase painting named for the color of its figures. The pseudonymous Sappho Painter, Theseus Painter, and Athena Painter were all named for painting vases in this style.

Black-figure vases are contrasted with a later school of painting named for this color, essentially reversing the background and figure colors of the previous style. Iron-rich clay was used to produce the pigment of this color.

Many of the finest examples of Greek vase painting are found on these large vessels used for diluting wine. Their “column” and “calyx” varieties were primarily painted in the black-figure style and their “bell” variety was primarily painted in the red-figure style.

bonuses.leadin: Steven Rinella describes his journey to hunt one of these animals in a 2018 book subtitled In Search of a Lost Icon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this animal that was hunted relentlessly in an effort to exterminate the Plains Indians and make way for the Transcontinental Railroad.

Those buffalo hunts were led by William Sherman and this former Union general, who reportedly remarked “the only good Indian is a dead one”. This Civil War general used “scorched-earth” tactics during his campaign in the Shenandoah Valley.

This general massacred the Cheyenne along the Washita River as part of the buffalo extermination campaign. This man also lost a battle where the only surviving member of his regiment was a horse named Comanche.

bonuses.leadin: In this play, Apollo argues that mothers are not related to their children, since they merely serve as vessels for the father’s offspring. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: his hair [or two locks of hair]
parts: Name this final play in Aeschylus’ (“ESS-kuh-liss’s”) Oresteia trilogy. At its end, Athena orders the Furies to become the title characters after a trial that resulted in Orestes’ acquittal.
Along with Euripides and Sophocles, Aeschylus is considered to be one of the three masters of this form of Athenian drama, the darker counterpart to comedy.
In The Libation Bearers, the second play in the Oresteia, Orestes puts some of this substance on his father Agamemnon’s grave as a way to honor him.

bonuses.leadin: One form of this technique involves adding cinnamon powder to create more showy flames. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: coq au vin [prompt on rooster/cock with wine]
parts: Name this cooking technique, which involves adding liquor to a hot pan, causing the dish to burst into fire. This technique is used to make dessert dishes such as Banana Fosters and Cherries Jubilee.
Along with rum, this is the most commonly used liquor for flambé. Varieties of this liquor include pisco and grappa, the latter of which is made from pomace instead of the typical fruit.

This french dish is sometimes prepared with a brandy flambé. This dish consists of chicken braised with lardon, mushrooms, and wine, most commonly a red Burgundy, although Jura, Alsace, or even Champagne may be used.

bonuses.leadin: Following his acquittal at the Fourth Lateran Council, this thinker's main text became the University of Paris' standard textbook. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Albertus Magnus [or Saint Albert the Great; or Albert of Cologne]
parts: Name this Scholastic philosopher who created the canonical list of the Seven Sacraments and wrote the Four Books of Sentences.

This philosopher famously wrote a three volume commentary on Lombard's Four Books of Sentences, as well as the Book of Causes and Precession of the Universe. This philosopher claimed that the goal of science is "to inquire into the causes of natural things" in De Mineralibus.
Albert Magnus' Book of Causes and Precession of the Universe served as a commentary on Aristotle's Organon, which is a collection of books in this field, which studies inferences and ways of reason.

bonuses.leadin: This battle’s outcome was partly due to the severe injury suffered by Brasidas at the previous Battle of Pylos. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 425 BC battle. This battle was notable because it was the first time a group of Spartans surrendered in the field of battle.
Donald Kagan said that the surrender at Sphacteria “shook the world” in a history of this conflict. Thucydides also documented this conflict.
The victorious Athenian general at Sphacteria had this name. Another Athenian of this name stuffed stones into his mouth to improve his oratory skills.

bonuses.leadin: A readily functionalized surface gel layer is formed from solvent penetration in the “solvent immersion imprinting” variant for this technique. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: photolithography [accept any specific type of lithography, such as optical/X-ray lithography; prompt on etching]
parts: Name this general technique used in microfabrication to pattern thin films and other high aspect ratio devices. This technique’s “optical” variant uses light to transfer patterns from a “photomask” onto its substrate.
These light-sensitive materials are the substrates in chemical lithography. These objects consist of an inactive resin and PAC or PAG spun onto a wafer. Common examples include SU-8 and DNQ-Novolac.

Wafers used in microfabrication are most commonly formed from the crystalline form of this element, which is used for its semiconducting properties. This element is also widely used in integrated circuits and computer chips.

bonuses.leadin: Moderator Note: DO NOT REVEAL the entire answerline for the first part of this bonus. A composition of this type that was “made for the night of Christmas” ends with a Pastorale Ad Libitum final movement in the key of G major. For 10 points each,
answers_sanitized: concerto grosso [DO NOT accept or prompt on “Concerto” alone: Accept but DO NOT REVEAL concerto da chiesa or sonata da chiesa]

concerto da chiesa and concerto da camera [accept sonata da chiesa and sonata da camera; accept church concerto and chamber concerto; accept church sonata or chamber sonata; prompt on 1 answer, but both answers are required]
parts: Name this type of composition, 12 of which comprise Arcangelo Correlli’s Opus 6. In contrast with a related “solo” type of composition, compositions of this type include a small group of soloists, the concertino, and the orchestral accompaniment, the ripieno.

These are the names of the 2 distinct forms of all concerti grossi. Trio sonatas are also classified into distinct genres that are given these two names, one of which featured more lively dances and the other more pious material. Name both.
This Baroque composer also wrote many concerti grossi, but is better known for composing Water Music and the oratorio Messiah.

bonuses.leadin: In a short story, one of these animals is told “You only need to change your direction” before being eaten. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of animal, one of which says “the world gets smaller everyday” in the very short story “A Little Fable.”
This author’s mouse-related stories include “A Little Fable” and “Josephine the Singer,” the latter of which is found in his collection A Hunger Artist.
Gregor Samsa wakes up one morning to discover he turned into an insect in this Kafka novella.

bonuses.leadin: These compounds typically possess multiple, decreasing dissociation constants, and their fractional concentrations can be calculated by knowing either the pH or the conjugate base concentrations. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: polyprotic acids [accept polybasic acids; accept diprotic or triprotic; prompt on acid(s)]
parts: Name these compounds capable of donating multiple protons or hydrogen atoms to an aqueous solution.

Concentrations of different polyprotic acids are visualized as a function of pH on one of these plots. These plots are most commonly used to analyze carbonate compounds and the impact of ocean acidification.

Polyprotic acids are easily identified because they produce multiple equivalence points in this simple laboratory technique in which samples are passed through a buret and are slowly added to a solution of known concentration.

bonuses.leadin: This religious order was first introduced to the western world by the proselytizing activities of the Inayati Order. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mystical form of Islam, which was practiced by al-Ghazali and Ibn Arabi. The Mevlevi order of this tradition are known as "whirling dervishes" for their practice of spinning as a way of connecting to God.

Sufism had a strong influence on this spiritual master and founder of Sufism Reoriented. This author of God Speaks was known for carrying out a 44 year vow of silence, teaching using an alphabet board and hand gestures.

Inayat Khan, the founder of the International Sufi Movement, centered his belief on the unity of God with all things, which he referred to with this term. This Arabic term is more commonly used to refer to the Islamic belief in monotheism.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s grandson Oleg played him in the 1981 film Reds. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Whites [or White Movement or White Army]
Symon Petliura [or Symon Vasylevych Petliura; also spelled Petlyura]
parts: Name this Russian leader. His dismissal of General Lavr Kornilov tanked his popularity as the leader of Russia’s provisional government during World War I.
Kerensky opposed both the Bolshevik “Reds” and this other faction that clashed with the Reds during the Civil War.

This interwar Ukrainian leader fought against the Whites during the Russian Civil War. He was assassinated by Sholom Schwartzbard for carrying out pogroms, and Schwartzbard was forced to only pay one franc to the relatives of this man.
